body: AT last count, the guest list tonight includes Matilda, Geb Ra, Murphy and his brother Ed, and Lucy. body: AMY BENNETT and Morton Dubin, both lawyers, were looking for an apartment to buy on the Upper West Side. One weekend, they went to an open house on 71st Street and were totally depressed by the minuscule bedrooms and pathetic outdoor space. ''It was $750,000 for two closets and a shared garden,'' Mr. Dubin said. On impulse, they jumped on the
title: Habitats /Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn; Couple Find Fort Greene Is Just to Their Taste

body: NEW YORK OCEANSIDE: LAUNDRY WORKERS SETTLE More than 250 striking workers at a large industrial laundry, Oceanside Institutional Industries, returned to work yesterday after the company agreed to the workers' demands for union recognition. The company agreed that the workers' collective bargaining agent would be the Union of Needletrades,
title: METRO BRIEFING

body: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: GUILTY PLEA IN PARK ATTACKS -- A Bronx man yesterday became the first indicted defendant to plead guilty to charges stemming from sexual attacks on women in Central Park after the Puerto Rican Day Parade in June. The man, Imanuel Nunez, 18, pleaded guilty to first-degree riot, admitting that he was part of a large group of men
title: METRO BRIEFING

body: Worried that most public high schools are not good enough for their children, middle-class and affluent parents across New York City have begun campaigning for a return to the traditional neighborhood high school. The movement, based in affluent enclaves from the Upper East Side to Park Slope in Brooklyn and Riverdale in the Bronx, is led by
title: Parents Want High Schoolers Closer to Home

body: Four of the nine members of Brooklyn's Community School Board 15 have asked Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy to consider firing the district's superintendent and several of his senior deputies following accusations of financial mismanagement and cuts in services at district schools. The request comes less than a year after the District 15 board
title: Levy Is Urged to Consider Firing a Brooklyn Superintendent

body: A Brooklyn school district failed to request competitive bids for three staff conferences at hotels in the last two years and then greatly exceeded Board of Education spending limits, according to an audit released yesterday by the city comptroller. Community School District 15, which includes the Park Slope, Carroll Gardens, Red Hook and Cobble
title: Brooklyn School District Exceeded Spending Caps for Conferences, Audit Says

body: ON a stormy evening last May, silvery voices could be heard floating down the halls of Public School 321 in Park Slope. ''To-may-to! To-mah-to! Po-tay-to! Po-tah-to! title: The Quest to Reinvent John Jay

body: As New Yorkers grapple with area code angst, worrying about who is worthy of (212) and who gets stuck with (646), Brooklynites are defiantly wearing their area code (718) on their chests. title: PULSE; Area Dress Code

body: Much like Manhattan, Brooklyn has never had a boroughwide multiple listing of homes for sale. title: Residential Real Estate; Multiple Listings Sought For Homes in Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: Your Aug. 16 news article about the controversy surrounding the proposed Brooklyn Bridge Park correctly reports that the Brooklyn Heights Association endorses the vision of a major park on our downtown waterfront. So do the associations representing the adjacent neighborhoods of Cobble Hill, Dumbo, Fort Greene and Fulton Ferry
title: A Waterfront Park for Brooklyn?

body: Joe McCarthy sees Redcoats everywhere in Brooklyn. In his mind's eye, British troops come surging by the tens of thousands off the war boats massed in the Narrows off Bay Ridge, just as they did on the humid, breezy morning of Aug. 27, 1776. They march in endless formation up Fourth Avenue, past the auto body places and worn bodegas, and pelt the
title: Red Cars, Not Coats, And a Cast Of One; Battle of Brooklyn, Evoked on a Budget

body: Standing next to the entrance of a Brooklyn subway station on a recent sweltering morning, Representative Edolphus Towns shook hands with the last in a trickling stream of rush hour workers and paused to make an observation about his campaign. ''Last time, I didn't do too much of this,'' the 66-year-old congressman said of his last primary race, in
title: Congressman Squares Off With Brooklyn Challenger

body: One woman was attacked last spring in Central Park by two strangers who beat and sexually abused her until she broke free and ran to safety on Manhattan's West Side. The attackers were convicted of aggravated sexual abuse and are serving long prison terms. Another woman was attacked last summer by a man who dragged her under the Coney Island
title: In Sex Crimes, Evidence Depends On Game of Chance in Hospitals

body: DEAR DIARY: I still look at computers with awe and trepidation and had asked a computer-whiz friend to help me install some software on the one I had at home. He wasn't sure if the problem in installing it was in my computer or in the installation disk, and needed to test the disk on another computer. I live in a large Manhattan apartment building,
title: Metropolitan Diary

body: Outsider art is folk, self-taught, naive or visionary, sometimes driven by psychological necessity. Many outsider artists are associated with rural areas, but several live and work in New York. Here are seven of them. CARLA CUBIT Attorney Street, Lower East Side She speaks in a barely audible whisper, but her bold mixed-media sculptures, built with
title: The Legacy of the Outsider

body: Bridget Claire Kule, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher A. Kule of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Brandon Wilson Lower, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Lower II of Winnetka, Ill. title: WEDDINGS; Bridget Kule, Brandon Lower

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Commercial Street Boxes Multiply, and So Does Irritation

body: A teacher at a Brooklyn high school was arrested Thursday night and accused of sexually abusing one of her students. The teacher, Nicole Philbert, 29, teaches global studies at Cobble Hill High School. There were four encounters between the teacher and her student, a 15-year-old boy, over four months at Ms. Philbert's home on Sullivan Street in
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Schoolteacher Accused In Sex Abuse of Student

body: Social workers took custody of a Brooklyn woman's two surviving children this week after the New York City medical examiner ruled that her 10-year-old son had died of starvation and dehydration. The child who died, David Jones, was one of triplets, and the two other children were placed together in a foster home, said Jennifer Falk, a spokeswoman
title: Siblings of Starved Boy Taken From Mother

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Serial Shoppers Who Terrorize Real Estate Agents

body: After decades of false starts and a near-demolition, a landmarked boathouse in Prospect Park will become home to the National Audubon Society's first-ever urban center. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT PARK; Bird Lovers Will Find a Home in a Beaux-Arts Boathouse

body: Residents of Carroll Gardens, Cobble Hill and Atlantic Avenue say the city is plowing through their streets to complete a water main replacement project with little regard for the havoc the project is wreaking in their neighborhood. Work began last summer on the three-year, $26.5 million project, which involves digging trenches along Clinton Street
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN; As Pipes Are Patched, Tempers Rise

body: Manhattan's loss is Brooklyn's gain. After failing to generate excitement at Scarabee in Midtown, Ken Johnson has pulled up stakes and taken his French-Mediterranean sensibility to Rustic, a small cafe in Cobble Hill. The change of air seems to be doing him good. In a no-frills, casual setting, he has devised a simplified menu that shows off his
title: DINER'S JOURNAL

body: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS and neighboring Cobble Hill have long been the home to locally owned businesses catering to the residents of the largely low-rise neighborhoods and the nearby court system. title: Commercial Property/Brooklyn Heights and Cobble Hill; National Chains Vie for Piece of the Local Retail Pie

body: DEAR DIARY: This is a tale of two cities. At the age of 3, I made my entry into Manhattan when my mother moved back from California. I spent the next 15 years living in poverty in a rooming house. This gave me the opportunity, as a young impressionable lad, to explore Gotham on foot. One day en route to Central Park, when I was 10 years old, I saw
title: Metropolitan Diary

body: It's not a job with a future, but the future of many neighborhoods in America may be affected by how well the job is done. Every 10 years, the Census Bureau hires an army of census takers -- enumerators, in bureau parlance. For the 2000 count, which has just begun, the bureau needs about a half-million of them. The job lasts only six weeks or so.
title: Census Takers Moved by Money And Civic Duty; A Temp Position That Counts, Even if It Doesn't Last Long

body: THE Gossip Columnist, Paula Froelich, age 26, writes for Page 6 of The New York Post. Wednesday, Jan. 26 8:30 a.m. Bagel and coffee in Cobble Hill apartment with view of Manhattan. 9:00 Dresses all in black; faint streak of glitter on each cheekbone. 10:15 Arrives at work, settles in cubicle shared with Ian Spiegelman, another Page 6 reporter.
title: What Do You Do All Day?

body: Rink-Side Seats The restaurants on the lower level of Rockefeller Center, which face the skating rink in winter and the garden in summer, have been reopened by Restaurant Associates. title: OFF THE MENU

body: Grasping a bar designed to help blind children keep their balance as they play, 4-year-old Monique jumps up and down on a small yellow trampoline. Suddenly, Joshua, a tall, husky boy, jumps on behind her. Ignoring the bar, he bounces hard, throwing her off balance. ''Stand up, Monique!'' cries one of her teachers. Monique frowns. ''He keeps
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL; Blind Children Take a Small Step Toward Public School

body: EVEN in this real estate market, when many houses and apartments generate instant bidding wars, some properties sit around a long time. Sometimes deals are made but fall apart. body: Where a developer recently envisioned an upscale marina and an ultramodern hotel, park planners now want to build a marsh. About 150 years after the natural shoreline disappeared, replaced by bulkheads and piers, state officials and the Brooklyn Bridge Park Development Corporation hope to return estuary grasses to a cove near the Manhattan Bridge.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO; New Hotel? No Thanks, They'd Prefer a Marsh
